intro: Ophrys × brigittae nothosubsp. brigittae, commonly known as the hybrid bee orchid, is a rare and fascinating plant species that exhibits unique botanical characteristics. It is a hybrid between Ophrys apifera (the bee orchid) and Ophrys insectifera (the wasp orchid), resulting in a plant with distinctive floral morphology. The orchid's flowers closely resemble female wasps, a feature that plays a crucial role in its pollination strategy. It typically grows in calcareous soils and is found in specific regions of southern Europe. Due to its rarity and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a vulnerable species in its native range.
